facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the Punjab High Court

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave from the judgment of the Punjab High Court and arises out of a suit for possession of land brought by Munshi Ram, respondent.

facts.text: Suit for possession of land brought by Munshi Ram, respondent

anchor.surface_text: and arises out of a suit for possession of land brought by Munshi Ram, respondent. The following pedigree table will be useful in understanding the claim put forward by the respondent

facts.text: Munshi Ram is the plaintiff

anchor.surface_text: Munshi Ram -----------------------  adopted son  plaintiff Hans Raj Salig Ram  Defdt.

facts.text: Salig Ram is the defendant-appellant

anchor.surface_text: Hans Raj Salig Ram  Defdt.  Munshi Ram  adopted by Ata  The claim of Munshi Ram was with respect to the property left

facts.text: Munshi Ram was adopted by Ata

anchor.surface_text: Salig Ram  Defdt.  Munshi Ram  adopted by Ata  The claim of Munshi Ram was with respect to the property left by Nanak Chand

facts.text: There is no dispute about the property of Santu

anchor.surface_text: The claim of Munshi Ram was with respect to the property left by Nanak Chand who is his natural grandfather and also Santu. There is numberdispute number about the property of Santu

facts.text: Appeal concerns only the property of Nanak Chand

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute number about the property of Santu and we are companycerned in this appeal only with the property of Nanak Chand. Nanak Chand died in 1939.

facts.text: Nanak Chand died in 1939

anchor.surface_text: Nanak Chand died in 1939. Munshi Rams natural father Hans Raj had pre-deceased Nanak Chand. Munshi Ram himself was adopted by Ata in 1918

facts.text: Munshi Ram's natural father Hans Raj had pre-deceased Nanak Chand

anchor.surface_text: Munshi Rams natural father Hans Raj had pre-deceased Nanak Chand. Munshi Ram himself was adopted by Ata in 1918 before the death of his natural father Hans Raj

facts.text: Munshi Ram was adopted by Ata in 1918

anchor.surface_text: Munshi Ram himself was adopted by Ata in 1918 before the death of his natural father Hans Raj which took place in 1920.

facts.text: Hans Raj died in 1920

anchor.surface_text: before the death of his natural father Hans Raj which took place in 1920. It will be clear from these dates therefore that Hans Raj never succeeded

facts.text: Hans Raj never succeeded to the property of his father Nanak Chand

anchor.surface_text: It will be clear from these dates therefore that Hans Raj never succeeded to the property of his father Nanak Chand and Munshi Ram had been adopted by Ata even before Hans Rajs death.

facts.text: Munshi Ram was entitled to one-half share of the property left by Nanak Chand as his heir according to Zamindara custom

anchor.surface_text: The case of Munshi Ram was that he was entitled to one-half share of the property left by Nanak Chand as his heir according to Zamindara custom. The parties, it may be mentioned, are Brahmins

facts.text: Parties are Brahmins

anchor.surface_text: The parties, it may be mentioned, are Brahmins and Munshi Ram claimed joint possession of the half share of the property left by Nanak Chand on his death.

facts.text: Salig Ram is the other son of Nanak Chand

anchor.surface_text: The suit was resisted by Salig Ram  defendant-appellant  who is the other son of Nanak Chand. His case was that Munshi Ram was number entitled

facts.text: Munshi Ram was not entitled either according to personal law or the Riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district to any share in the property left by Nanak Chand

anchor.surface_text: His case was that Munshi Ram was number entitled either according to personal law or the Riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district to any share in the property left by Nanak Chand. The trial companyrt held

facts.text: Trial court held that Munshi Ram was entitled to succeed to the property left by Nanak Chand along with Salig Ram and decreed the suit

anchor.surface_text: The trial companyrt held that Munshi Ram was entitled to succeed to the property left by Nanak Chand along with Salig Ram and decreed the suit accordingly. Salig Ram went in appeal to the District Judge

facts.text: Salig Ram appealed to the District Judge but failed

anchor.surface_text: Salig Ram went in appeal to the District Judge but failed. He then went in second appeal to the High Court but the second appeal was also dismissed.

facts.text: Salig Ram filed second appeal to the High Court which was dismissed

anchor.surface_text: He then went in second appeal to the High Court but the second appeal was also dismissed. The High Court having refused to grant a certificate

facts.text: High Court refused to grant a certificate

anchor.surface_text: The High Court having refused to grant a certificate the appellant applied to this Court from special leave which was granted

facts.text: Special leave was granted by this Court

anchor.surface_text: the appellant applied to this Court from special leave which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Munshi Ram was adopted by Ata according to custom during the lifetime of Hans Raj

anchor.surface_text: Munshi Rams, case was that he was adopted by Ata according to custom  i.e., in accordance with the mode prevalent in the companymunity for purposes of adoption  during the lifetime of Hans Raj.

facts.text: The adoption was not in the dvyamushyayana form

anchor.surface_text: Thus Munshi Ram having been adopted by Ata would have numberright left in the family of his natural father Hans Raj, unless the adoption was in the dvyamushyayana form.

facts.text: Riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district from 1865 stated that an adopted son will not be a co-sharer amongst his brothers in the property left by his natural father

anchor.surface_text: It appears that in 1865 the riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district stated that an adopted son will number be a companysharer amongst his brothers, in the property left by his natural father, i.e., a son given away

facts.text: Manual of Customary Law prepared in 1911-12 by Mr. Craik records custom for Brahmins and Khatris

anchor.surface_text: In any case the position is made clear by the Manual of Customary Law prepared in 1911-12 by Mr. Craik. The custom recorded in that companypilation is that with the exception of Brahmins

facts.text: Among Brahmins and Khatris, a son given away in adoption succeeds to the property of his natural father only if there is no other son

anchor.surface_text: The companyclusion therefore at which we arrive is that amongst Brahmins and Khatris of Amritsar district, a son given away in adoption can succeed to the property of his natural father only if there is numberother son

facts.text: Hans Raj died in the lifetime of Nanak Chand

anchor.surface_text: But Hans Raj, having died in the lifetime of his father  Nanak Chand , never succeeded to the property of his father.

facts.text: Munshi Ram is natural grandson of Nanak Chand

anchor.surface_text: Munshi Ram  adopted by Ata  The claim of Munshi Ram was with respect to the property left by Nanak Chand who is his natural grandfather

anchor.surface_text: The case of Munshi Ram was that he was entitled to one-half share of the property left by Nanak Chand as his heir according to Zamindara custom. The parties, it may be mentioned, are Brahmins and Munshi Ram claimed joint possession of the half share of the property left by Nanak Chand on his death.

issues.text: Whether Hindu law applies in the first instance to succession matters for Hindus in Punjab unless custom proved under s.5 Punjab Laws Act

anchor.surface_text: s. 5 of the Punjab Laws Act, No. IV of 1872. Clause  b  of that section provides that the rule of decision in such matters shall be the Hindu law where the parties are Hindus, except in so far as such law has been altered or abolished by legislative enactment, or is opposed to the provisions of this Act or has been modified by any such custom as is referred to in clause  a  thereof.

issues.text: What the Zamindara custom is in the present case regarding adopted son's right to natural family property

anchor.surface_text: But Munshi Rams case was that according to Zamindara custom he was entitled to succeed to half of the properties left by Nanak Chand. The question therefore arises what the Zamindara custom is in the present case. In the plaint the custom was number actually pleaded

issues.answer: adopted son succeeds only if no other son of natural father

issues.text: Whether para. 48 of Rattigan's Digest applies or the local custom in riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district prevails for Brahmins

anchor.surface_text: para. 48 of the Digest of Customary Law in the Punjab by Rattigan at p. 572, 13th Edition. This paragraph appears in section V dealing with Effect of Adoption on Succession and is in the following terms - An heir appointed in the manner above described ordinarily does number thereby lose his right to succeed to property in his natural family, as against companylaterals, but does number succeed in the presence of his natural brothers.

issues.answer: local custom prevails: exclusion if natural brothers; for Brahmins only if no other son

issues.text: Whether the burden lies on the party asserting custom at variance with Hindu law to prove it under Punjab Laws Act s.5

anchor.surface_text: the position therefore that emerges is, where the parties are Hindus, the Hindu law would apply in the first instance and whosoever asserts a custom at variance with the Hindu law shall have to prove it, though the quantum of proof required in support of the custom which is general and well recognised may be small

issues.text: Whether Munshi Ram is entitled to succeed to Nanak Chand's property on the principle of representation as heir of predeceased father Hans Raj

anchor.surface_text: on the principle of representation Munshi Ram stepped into the shoes of Hans Raj and therefore was entitled to succeed to the estate left by Nanak Chand as his father would have succeeded if he had been alive at the time of the death of Nanak Chand. But if Munshi Ram is to succeed by the application of the principle of representation it would follow that Munshi Ram would really be deemed to be Hans Raj

holdings.text: where the parties are Hindus, the Hindu law would apply in the first instance and whosoever asserts a custom at variance with the Hindu law shall have to prove it, though the quantum of proof required in support of the custom which is general and well recognised may be small while in other cases of what are called special customs the quantum may be larger

anchor.surface_text: the position therefore that emerges is, where the parties are Hindus, the Hindu law would apply in the first instance and whosoever asserts a custom at variance with the Hindu law shall have to prove it, though the quantum of proof required in support of the custom which is general and well recognised may be small

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct interpretation of s.5 Punjab Laws Act clauses (a) and (b); burden confirmed by precedents including Privy Council and Supreme Court cases

holdings.text: Munshi Ram having been adopted by Ata would have no right left in the family of his natural father Hans Raj, unless the adoption was in the dvyamushyayana form and so far as Hindu law is concerned, if it applies to this case Munshi Ram would not be entitled after the adoption to succeed to the property left by Nanak Chand

anchor.surface_text: Thus Munshi Ram having been adopted by Ata would have no right left in the family of his natural father Hans Raj, unless the adoption was in the dvyamushyayana form. It was however never the case

holdings.reasoning_summary: Under Hindu law, ordinary adoption severs all rights in natural family absent special dvyamushyayana form, which was not claimed

holdings.text: there is therefore an initial presumption of correctness as regards the entries in the Riwaj-i-am and when the custom as recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in conflict with the general custom as recorded in Rattigans Digest or ascertained otherwise, the entries in the Riwaj-i-am should ordinarily prevail

anchor.surface_text: there is therefore an initial presumption of correctness as regards the entries in the Riwaj-i-am and when the custom as recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in conflict with the general custom as recorded in Rattigans Digest or ascertained otherwise, the entries in the Riwaj-i-am should ordinarily prevail

holdings.reasoning_summary: Per Jai Kaur precedent, local Riwaj-i-am entries prevail over general custom like Rattigan para 48, strengthened as no female rights adversely affected

holdings.text: amongst Brahmins and Khatris of Amritsar district, a son given away in adoption can succeed to the property of his natural father only if there is no other son of the natural father if there is another son he cannot succeed
holdings.reasoning_summary: Synthesizing 1865 Riwaj-i-am, 1911-12 Craik Manual (exception for Brahmins/Khatris if no other son), 1940 compilation, and statements; distinguishing Majja Singh (Jats, only son)

holdings.text: if Munshi Ram is to succeed on the principle of representation that principle must be fully worked out and he must for all intents and purposes be deemed to be Hans Raj. As the person who is deemed to be Hans Raj was adopted away and has a brother in the shape of Salig Ram he would not succeed even under the custom recorded in para. 48 of Rattigans Digest
holdings.reasoning_summary: Representation principle requires complete fictional substitution as predeceased father, including adoption severance, leading to exclusion by surviving natural brother under custom or Hindu law

holdings.text: neither under Hindu law nor under the custom recorded in para. 48 can Munshi Ram succeed to the property of Nanak Chand
holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-adoption severance under Hindu law; custom excludes adopted son where natural brother exists; representation fully applied confirms exclusion

precedents.citation: Daya Ram v. Sohel Singh and others 1906 P.R. No. 110.

anchor.surface_text: Daya Ram v. Sohel Singh and others 1906 P.R. No. 110., in all cases under s. 5 of the Punjab laws Act, it lies upon the person asserting that he is ruled in regard to a particular matter by custom, to prove that he is so governed, and number by personal law, and further to prove what the particular custom is. There is numberpresumption created by the clause in favour of custom on the companytrary it is only when the custom is established that it is to be the rule of decision.

precedents.cited_proposition: In all cases under s. 5 of the Punjab Laws Act, it lies upon the person asserting custom to prove it governs them rather than personal law, and to prove the custom; no presumption in favour of custom.

precedents.citation: Abdul Hussein Khan v. Bibi Sona Dero and another  1917  L.R. 45 I.A. 10, 13

anchor.surface_text: Abdul Hussein Khan v. Bibi Sona Dero and another  1917  L.R. 45 I.A. 10, 13 The same view has been taken by this Court in Ujagar Singh v. Mst. Jeo 1959 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 781 We have therefore in the first instance to apply Hindu law to the parties to this suit, and it is only when a custom different from Hindu law is proved that rights of the parties would be governed by that custom.

precedents.case_name: Abdul Hussein Khan v. Bibi Sona Dero
precedents.cited_proposition: Approved the observations on burden of proof for custom under s. 5 Punjab Laws Act.

precedents.citation: Ujagar Singh v. Mst. Jeo 1959 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 781

anchor.surface_text: Ujagar Singh v. Mst. Jeo 1959 Supp. 2 S.C.R. 781 We have therefore in the first instance to apply Hindu law to the parties to this suit, and it is only when a custom different from Hindu law is proved that rights of the parties would be governed by that custom. Munshi Rams, case was that he was adopted by Ata according to custom  i.e., in accordance with the mode prevalent in the companymunity for purposes of adoption  during the lifetime of Hans Raj.

precedents.cited_proposition: Took the same view on burden of proving custom over Hindu law.

precedents.citation: Jai Kaur and others v. Sher Singh and others

anchor.surface_text: Jai Kaur and others v. Sher Singh and others , where this Court held that - there is therefore an initial presumption of companyrectness as regards the entries in the Riwaj-i-am and when the custom as recorded in the Riwaj-i-am is in companyflict with the general custom as recorded in Rattigans Digest or ascertained otherwise, the entries in the Riwaj-i-am should ordinarily prevail except that as was pointed out by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in a recent decision in Mt. Subhani v. Nawab , that where, as in the present case, the Riwaj-i-am affects adversely the rights of females who had numberopportunity whatever of appearing before the revenue authorities, the presumption would be weak, and only a few instances would suffice to rebut it.

precedents.cited_proposition: Initial presumption of correctness for entries in Riwaj-i-am over general custom in conflict; prevails ordinarily, but weak if adversely affects females without representation.

anchor.surface_text: as was pointed out by the Judicial Committee of the Privy Council in a recent decision in Mt. Subhani v. Nawab , that where, as in the present case, the Riwaj-i-am affects adversely the rights of females who had numberopportunity whatever of appearing before the revenue authorities, the presumption would be weak, and only a few instances would suffice to rebut it. As females are number companycerned in this case, the entries in the riwaj-i-am of Amritsar district in 1865, if they companyflict with para. 48 of Rattigans Digest, should prevail.

precedents.cited_proposition: Presumption of correctness of Riwaj-i-am weak where it adversely affects females without opportunity to appear before authorities.

precedents.citation: Majja Singh and others v. Ram Singh 1879 P.R. No. 43

anchor.surface_text: Majja Singh and others v. Ram Singh 1879 P.R. No. 43 That was however a case of Jats and number of Brahmins and the person who was adopted in that case was an only son. That case would number therefore necessarily override the custom so far as it applies to Brahmins.

precedents.cited_proposition: Did not accept the Riwaj-i-am of Amritsar 1865 as correct custom.
